Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Ambient air pollution and risk of type 2 diabetes in the Chinese.

AbstractText: We performed a time series analysis to investigate the potential association between exposure to ambient air pollution and type 2 diabetes (T2D) incidence in the Chinese population. Monthly time series data between 2008 and 2015 on ambient air pollutants and incident T2D (N = 25,130) were obtained from the Environment Monitoring Center of Ningbo and the Chronic Disease Surveillance System of Ningbo. Relative risks (RRs) and 95% confidence intervals (95% CIs) of incident T2D per 10 μg/m<sup>3</sup> increases in ambient air pollutants were estimated from Poisson generalized additive models. Exposure to particulate matter < 10 μm (PM<sub>10</sub>) and sulfur dioxide (SO<sub>2</sub>) was associated with increased T2D incidence. The relative risks (RRs) of each increment in 10 μg/m<sup>3</sup> of PM<sub>10</sub> and SO<sub>2</sub> were 1.62 (95% CI, 1.16-2.28) and 1.63 (95% CI, 1.12-2.38) for overall participants, whereas for ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) exposure, the RRs were 0.78 (95% CI, 0.68-0.90) for overall participants, 0.78 (95% CI, 0.69-0.90) for males, and 0.78 (95% CI, 0.67-0.91) for females, respectively. Exposure to PM<sub>10</sub> and SO<sub>2</sub> is positively associated with T2D incidence, whereas O<sub>3</sub> is negatively associated with T2D incidence.
